Semaphore

This components helps decode or encode in the Flag semaphore telegraphy system.

Basic usage

Any semaphore character is represented by the position of a pair of flags, each in one of eight possible directions. These eight directions correspond to the eight highlighted areas of screen. A pair can be entered by tapping two appropriate circular marks, simultaneously using two fingers, or in a swipe.

As long as just one circle has been highlighted, all the characters having one of their flags in that direction are listed as suggestions. Aside from tapping the second circle, a character can be selected from these suggestions.

Variants

If the decoded string makes little sense, it has been perhaps obfuscated by the author of the puzzle by turning or reflecting the semaphore signs (this may also be the result of representing the directions by numbers in incompatible ways as there is no standard numbering). For these situations, Semaphore offers the Variants tab, where the previously entered input is reconsidered in a rotated and/or mirrored coordinate system. All possible transformations of this kind are listed.

NB that the occurrence of the number sign (see below) may result in different lengths of the variants.

Encryption

The Encrypt tab can be used to encode an input string into the semaphore alphabet. The output can be obtained in a graphical or numeric representation. The former can be exported as a PNG file (in black on white background), the latter in plain text, which might be more useful if further processed. In the numeric representation, each character is converted to a pair of digits in the range 1 through 8 where the numbering is chosen so that A, B, C, …, G correspond to 12, 13, 14, …, 18.

Preferences

By default the component is set up to recognize the 26 English letters and a number sign. This leaves only one unassigned combination. The number sign switches the interpretation of the first 11 combinations (originally letters A through K) to digits 1–9 and 0 (K), J becoming the \"character sign\" which reverses the assignments to normal. The number sign can be disabled in the preferences so that it stays unrecognized and the switching to numeric mode never occurs.

Tips and tricks

If the numeric mode is entered by mistake and you wish to exit it promptly instead of remembering the character sign, use BackSpace.
